Today's topic is about coping with grief.

Grief affects us all in different ways.

Whatever you feel, you are grieving in your own way, and that is okay.

media_title.eng: Why is taking care of ourselves important during times of grief?

media_transcript.eng:
Greetings.

Today's topic is coping with grief.

Taking care of ourselves is important, especially when we are facing challenging and difficult times such as coping with grief. We need to stay calm in order to think and act positively whenever we find ourselves overwhelmed. We may use techniques such as taking a pause to calm ourselves down.

rows.media_title: Why is taking care of ourselves important during times of grief?
rows.media_transcript:
Greetings.

Today's topic is coping with grief.

Taking care of ourselves is important, especially when we are facing challenging and difficult times such as coping with grief. We need to stay calm in order to think and act positively whenever we find ourselves overwhelmed. We may use techniques such as taking a pause to calm ourselves down.

rows.text_1_facilitator:
Taking care of ourselves during grief helps us stay calm and present for our children. 
When we share and name our feelings openly, it can help the whole family feel less alone and more supported.

text_1_facilitator.eng:
Taking care of ourselves during grief helps us stay calm and present for our children. 
When we share and name our feelings openly, it can help the whole family feel less alone and more supported.

media_title.eng: Hear how a parent and teen supported each other

media_transcript.eng:
After I lost my husband, the parenting tips that I learnt were so helpful to me: I began breathing calmly whenever I was feeling so sad or angry, and my kids really felt the difference because I was learning to keep calm.

Naming our feelings and being open about how we are feeling has helped me feel closer to my child. Before, I felt like I was the only one who was going through these emotions, but now I know that my child is feeling the same things. We can talk about it and help each other. We don’t feel alone anymore.

rows.text_1_facilitator: Here are this week’s takeaway skills to help you and your family through times of grief.

text_1_facilitator.eng: Here are this week’s takeaway skills to help you and your family through times of grief.

section_1_text.eng:
Losing someone we love can affect us for weeks, months or years. You do not have to feel better quickly, and there is no right or wrong way to grieve.

Your teen may feel sad, angry, not understand or not believe it, or feel unwell. They may have pains, nightmares, or problems at school. They may seem happy, but still feel sad. All of this is normal.

section_2_text.eng:
Find a way to say goodbye that feels right for you and your family. Some people hold a ceremony or have a special meal to celebrate the person.

Ask your teen what they would want to do to say goodbye.

section_3_text.eng:
It can help just to talk about the person when you think about them or write down how you feel. Share your memories, the good ones and the difficult ones.

Children may feel like the person’s death was their fault or that they behaved badly. Tell them clearly that they did nothing wrong. Explain that your teen can always tell you how they feel, and encourage them by also sharing how you feel.

media_title.eng: Hear how this changed things for one teenager

media_transcript.eng:
When I lost my mom, everything changed. I was so sad, but it felt like my dad couldn't understand. Our relationship suffered. We did our own things and we stopped talking to each other. But then something incredible happened.

My dad learnt all these things from the app about what to do when you lose someone. He asked me how I was doing and we started to talk again. He explained that he was sad too, and he even said he was sorry for not talking to me after my mom died. We can now see that it is hard for both of us, and we can help each other. He is supporting me and we are a lot closer.
